University officials have succeeded in eliminating a S1.6 million deficit present in the preliminary budget projection for fiscal
year 1976.
The final draft of a proposed
balanced budget for next year
was mailed to the Budget and
Audit Committee of the Board of
Trustees March 19. .
The balanced budget proposal
is in compliance with President
Muller's mandate to University
fiscal officers that the 1976 budget be balanced.

Festival of Women and Germaine Greer: who's next?
By PAT FLANNERY
Amidst the activities of Hopkins'
"Next Step: A Women's Festival," it
might prove useful to take a step back
from the situation and figure out exactly
where women are in 1975.
The initial furor of the Women's Liber
ation Movement has admittedly passed.
The shrill voices of the trail-blazing 'radical libbers' are slowly but surely fading.
Certain changes have occured over the
years—but what exactly are they, and
how much do they really mean?
Formerly radical tenets of the original
movement have been gradually assimilated into the American consciousness. The
once-burning issues of whether or not a
woman should wear a bra or shave her
legs have been resolved by most on the
simple basis of personal preference. Ideologies can be as restricting as they are liberating. So, some have chosen to 'liberate'
their bodies, some have not. Hairy legs a
feminist do not make.
Cries from feminists for sexual liberation generated considerable opposition
at one time. Now, however,'free love' has
become passe. Calculations determining
the degree of actual change in sexual attitudes shall be left to qualified sociologists. This movement for honest sexual relationships has been perversely 'Americanized' as is indicated by the advent of
publications such as 'Playgirl' and their
increasing popularity. Evidently, certain
people feel that women who decried their
sexploitation of centuries were merely demanding equal privileges. So, women have
been conferred the dubious right to enjoy
sexploitation on' an equal basis with men
in the time-honored American tradition

as further proof of their emancipation.
Many people believe that the women's
liberation movement has made its biggest
impact on the field of employment opportunities. However, the persistence of
quota systems and tokenism in both universities and job situations prove that
women have yet to be fully accepted as
equally competent members of the intellectual or working forces. Female secretaries are always in demand, yes, but toplevel positions are still predominantly
male bastions.
What many fail* to realize is tilat the
working mother is no longer an anachronism—she represents an economic reality. Career women are not 'super' ambitious or 'unusually' intelligent female anomalies. They're working for the same
reasons men are, and have the same stakes
in the job game.
Perhaps this reality is ignored because
the fallacious belief that women must
make a choice between job and a family
is still preivalent today. The element of
choice is quickly disappearing. Yet the
number of available jobs equal to many
women's capacities lags far behind the
number anxious to fill them.
What these 'changes' amount to, then,
is tokenism at best, and warped interpretations of the original intentions at worst,
in response to the demands of feminists
to date.
The burning issue now is this: will
women accept these meaningless, symbolic gestures of 'victory', or will they
move on towards their real goal—full acceptance of woman as completely integrated, self-actualized totalities?
Women's Liberation can no longer be

an end in itself. The raw material which it
provides—self-actualized women ready to
take their place in the social scheme of
things—must be converted into a viable
socio-political force.
Some women have taken the first
strides towards such a conversion. Women
like Germaine Greer, for example. Ms.
Greer epitomizes the self-actualized woman. Her brilliant discourse on "Fertility
and Women" revealed the many facets of
her well-integrated personality: she is
realistic, yet compassionate, intelligently
calculating, yet warmly human. She has
conquered the dualisms which are forced
upon women in the name of liberation—
the fallaciously forced choices between
motherhood or a career, aggression or
passivity, superior intelligence or vacuous
stupidity.

Authoress of the feminist manifesto
The Female Eunuch (1970), Ms. Greer
has participated actively in the women's
movement from its early stages to the
present. Commening on the designation
by the United Nations of 1975 as
'International Women's Year', Ms. Greer
stated that "...It's no surprise that the
one following Population Year is International Women's Year." Responding to
Isaac Asimov's reported prediction that,
"In the future, because of the population
scare, women will have to be liberated if
they like it or not," Ms. Greeer exclaimed, "Imagine turning liberation into tyranny."
"Mr. Asimov and his kind are relying
on the supposed anti-natalism of Women's Liberation. We are objecting to the
fact that we must be child-bearing, not

that we can. We object that women are
punished in this society for their child-bearing function.—

unless it was politically desirable, Ms.
Greer stated that "Women's wombs are
not theirs to control—they are regarded as
a resource of the state. Women's fertility
is as much a resource as mineral
deposits."
Essentially concerned with the issue of
human ethics and population control, Ms.
Greer expounded at length on the failure
of Western birth control methods in
Third World nations such as India. Traditional Indian methods for solving the
population problem, such as painless infanticide, have been replaced by the moral Western solution of death by starvation.
Ms. Greer's central argument was that
"...we cannot pre. empt these people's
choices—we will become ethically imperialistic."
"There is no choice between right and
wrong in these matters. It is between
right and right, or wrong and wrong. But
one cannot avoid risking his soul, and the
ghastliness of moral dilemna by merely
taking the least line of resistance. One
cannot merely obey the law.
"The law is not a substitute for morality. At some point, we must have the
courage to sin. We know too much—after
such knowledge, what forgiveness?"
Germaine Greer acts upon the courage
of her convictions, as a woman, yes, but
more importantly, as a fully-integrated
human being. She has already taken the
next step—who's next?

distant agonies of American involvement in Southeast Asia,

participated for over a decade. The news media's graphic

Festival of Women and Germaine Greer: who's next?
By PAT FLANNERY
Amidst the activities of Hopkins'
"Next Step: A Women's Festival," it
might prove useful to take a step back
from the situation and figure out exactly
where women are in 1975.
The initial furor of the Women's Liber
ation Movement has admittedly passed.
The shrill voices of the trail-blazing 'radical libbers' are slowly but surely fading.
Certain changes have occured over the
years—but what exactly are they, and
how much do they really mean?
Formerly radical tenets of the original
movement have been gradually assimilated into the American consciousness. The
once-burning issues of whether or not a
woman should wear a bra or shave her
legs have been resolved by most on the
simple basis of personal preference. Ideologies can be as restricting as they are liberating. So, some have chosen to 'liberate'
their bodies, some have not. Hairy legs a
feminist do not make.
Cries from feminists for sexual liberation generated considerable opposition
at one time. Now, however,'free love' has
become passe. Calculations determining
the degree of actual change in sexual attitudes shall be left to qualified sociologists. This movement for honest sexual relationships has been perversely 'Americanized' as is indicated by the advent of
publications such as 'Playgirl' and their
increasing popularity. Evidently, certain
people feel that women who decried their
sexploitation of centuries were merely demanding equal privileges. So, women have
been conferred the dubious right to enjoy
sexploitation on' an equal basis with men
in the time-honored American tradition

as further proof of their emancipation.
Many people believe that the women's
liberation movement has made its biggest
impact on the field of employment opportunities. However, the persistence of
quota systems and tokenism in both universities and job situations prove that
women have yet to be fully accepted as
equally competent members of the intellectual or working forces. Female secretaries are always in demand, yes, but toplevel positions are still predominantly
male bastions.
What many fail* to realize is tilat the
working mother is no longer an anachronism—she represents an economic reality. Career women are not 'super' ambitious or 'unusually' intelligent female anomalies. They're working for the same
reasons men are, and have the same stakes
in the job game.
Perhaps this reality is ignored because
the fallacious belief that women must
make a choice between job and a family
is still preivalent today. The element of
choice is quickly disappearing. Yet the
number of available jobs equal to many
women's capacities lags far behind the
number anxious to fill them.
What these 'changes' amount to, then,
is tokenism at best, and warped interpretations of the original intentions at worst,
in response to the demands of feminists
to date.
The burning issue now is this: will
women accept these meaningless, symbolic gestures of 'victory', or will they
move on towards their real goal—full acceptance of woman as completely integrated, self-actualized totalities?
Women's Liberation can no longer be

provides—self-actualized women ready to

things—must be converted into a viable
socio-political force.

like Germaine Greer, for example. Ms.

and Women" revealed the many facets of

cannot merely obey the law.

such knowledge, what forgiveness?"

more importantly, as a fully-integrated
human being. She has already taken the
next step—who's next?
